facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment dated October 6, 1958 of Punjab High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No. 52 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 6, 1958, of the Punjab High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No. 52 of 1954,

facts.text: Letters Patent Appeal No. 52 of 1954 arose out of judgment dated June 15, 1954 of Punjab High Court in First Appeal from Order No. 149 of 1953.

facts.text: Appellant executed two usufructuary mortgages for two properties in Ferozepore city in favour of respondents in 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The brief facts necessary for present purposes are these. The appellant had executed two usufructuary mortgages with respect to two properties situate in Ferozepore city in favour of the respondents in 1946.

facts.text: Appellant took both properties on lease on the same date as the mortgages.

anchor.surface_text: She also took both properties on lease on the same date.

facts.text: Respondents filed application under s. 13 of Displaced Persons (Debts Adjustment) Act, 1951 for recovery of principal sum due and rent arrears.

anchor.surface_text: An application was filed by the respondents under s. 13 of the Displaced Persons  Debts Adjustment  Act, No. LXX of 1951  hereinafter called the Act , for recovery of the principal sum due as well as the rent which was said to be in arrears.

facts.text: Appellant resisted the application on grounds including that no such application lay as liability was not a debt under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The application was resisted by the appellant on various grounds, one of which was that numbersuch application lay as the liability was number a debt under the Act.

facts.text: Tribunal negatived appellant's contention and passed preliminary decree for sale.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal negatived the companytention of the appellant and passed a preliminary decree for sale.

facts.text: Tribunal allowed six months time to appellant to pay decretal amount, failing which respondents could get final decree and sell properties.

anchor.surface_text: Six months time was allowed to the appellant to pay the decretal amount, failing which the respondents were at liberty to get a final decree prepared and bring the properties to sale.

facts.text: Appellant's appeal to High Court was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant went in appeal to the High Court but the appeal was dismissed.

facts.text: Letters Patent Appeal was dismissed by Punjab High Court on October 6, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Then there was a Letters Patent Appeal, which was also dismissed.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The appel- lant then applied for and was granted special leave by this Court,

facts.text: Properties are situate in Ferozepore city.

anchor.surface_text: two properties situate in Ferozepore city in favour of the respondents

facts.text: Liability under the mortgage is contested by appellant as not being a debt under s. 2(6) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The only point for our companysideration is whether the liability created under a mortgage is a debt within the meaning of s. 2 6  of the Act.

facts.text: Court held that mortgage creates pecuniary liability which is a debt under s. 2(6).

concepts.unlisted_description: Definition of 'debt' as pecuniary liability with subclauses (a),(b),(c).

anchor.surface_text: The relevant part of that provision runs as follows- Debt means any pecuniary liability, whether payable presently or in future, or under a decree or order of civil or revenue court or otherwise, or whether ascertained or to be ascertained, which (a) in the case of a displaced person who has left or been displaced from his place of residence in any area now forming part of West Pakistan, was incurred before he came to reside in any area now forming part of India (b) in the case of a displaced person who, before and after the 15th day of August, 1947, has been residing in any area now forming part of India, was incurred before the said date on the security of any immovable property situate in the territories now forming part of West Pakistan Provided that where any such liability was incurred on the security of immovable properties situate both in India and in West Pakistan, the liability shall be so apportioned between the said properties that the liability in relation to each of the said properties bears the same proportion to the total amount of the debts as the value of each of the properties as at the date of the transaction bears to the total value of the properties furnished as security, and the liability, for the purposes of this clause, shall be the liability which is relatable to the property in West Pakistan (c) is due to a displaced person from any other person (whether a displaced person or not) ordinarily residing in the territories to which this Act extends x x x x

holdings.text: The liability created under a mortgage is a debt within the meaning of s. 2(6) of the Act as it constitutes a pecuniary liability.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that there is noforce in this contention. The words pecuniary liability will cover any liability which is of a monetary nature. Now the definition of a mortgage in s. 58 of the Transfer of Property Act, No. 4 of 1882, shows that though it is the transfer of an interest in specific immovable property, the purpose of the transfer is to secure the payment of money advanced or to be advanced by way of loan or to secure an existing or future debt or the performance of an engagement which may give rise to a pecuniary liability. The money advanced by way of loan, for example, which is secured by a mortgage, obviously creates a pecuniary liability. It is true that a mortgage in addition to creating the pecuniary liability also transfers interest in the specific immovable property to secure that liability nonetheless the loan or debt to secure which the mortgage is created will remain a pecuniary liability of the person creating the mortgage. Therefore a mortgage debt would create a pecuniary liability upon the mortgagor and would be covered by the definition of the word debt in s. 2(6).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pecuniary liability includes any monetary obligation; s.58 TPA defines mortgage as securing payment of money, loan, debt, or engagement giving rise to pecuniary liability, thus mortgage creates pecuniary liability on mortgagor.

holdings.text: Nothing in the scheme or provisions of the Act militates against or cuts down the plain meaning of 'pecuniary liability' in s. 2(6)(c).

anchor.surface_text: Let us now see whether there is anything in the scheme of the Act which in any way militates against the plain words of s. 2(6). Learned counsel for the appellant in the first place refers to sub-cl. (b) of s. 2(6) in this connection and points out that that subclause specifically deals with mortgage debts secured on any immovable property situate in the territories forming part of West Pakistan. ... Thus we see nothing in any provision of the Act or in its scheme which would cut down the meaning we have given to the words pecuniary liability as used in s. 2(6) read with sub-cl. (c) thereof.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Specific provisions like s.16(b) for Pakistan property mortgages create charges on compensation/exchange property and do not limit general s.2(6)(c); ss.17,21 general and do not exclude mortgages; repealed Acts show expansion to include all pecuniary liabilities including mortgages.

holdings.text: The Act provides machinery for enforcement of mortgage debts secured on property in India through ss.13,14(2),28 and application of CPC via s.25, overriding other laws per s.3.

anchor.surface_text: It was also urged that if mortgage debts on property situate in India were covered by the Act, there is no machinery like s. 16 for enforcement of the creditors rights in respect thereof. This is not correct. Section 10 provides for the claim of a displaced creditor against a displaced debtor and s. 13 provides for the claim of a displaced creditor against any other person who is not a displaced debtor. Section 14(2) a tribunal can pass such decree in relation to an application under s. 13 as it thinks fit. These decrees are executable under s. 28 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ss.10,13 for claims, s.14(2) for decrees as tribunal deems fit, executable per s.28; s.25 applies CPC; s.3 non-obstante overrides inconsistencies; differs from special s.16 for Pakistan property.

holdings.text: Proceedings under s.13 for mortgage debt do not prejudicially affect rights of prior or subsequent mortgagees.

anchor.surface_text: The last contention on behalf of the appellant is that if s. 2(6)(c) empowers a displaced creditor to make an application under s. 13 even with respect to a mortgage debt, there will be hardship to prior mortgagees or subsequent mortgagees inasmuch as these persons cannot be dealt with under the Act. ... Therefore, the interest of the prior mortgagee or the subsequent mortgagee, if any, would not be affected by a decree passed on an application under s. 13 and there is no reason therefore to cut down the plain meaning of the words used in s. 2(6)(c) on the ground that the proceedings under the Act would prejudicially affect the rights of prior or puisne mortgagees.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even if O.XXXIV r.1 CPC not fully applicable, prior mortgagee rights unaffected per Explanation; subsequent mortgagee not bound if not joined, can pursue mortgagor and follow property.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that there is noforce in this contention. The words pecuniary liability will cover any liability which is of a monetary nature. Now the definition of a mortgage in s. 58 of the Transfer of Property Act, No. 4 of 1882, shows that though it is the transfer of an interest in specific immovable property, the purpose of the transfer is to secure the payment of money advanced or to be advanced by way of loan or to secure an existing or future debt or the performance of an engagement which may give rise to a pecuniary liability. The money advanced by way of loan, for example, which is secured by a mortgage, obviously creates a pecuniary liability. It is true that a mortgage in addition to creating the pecuniary liability also transfers interest in the specific immovable property to secure that liability nonetheless the loan or debt to secure which the mortgage is created will remain a pecuniary liability of the person creating the mortgage. Therefore a mortgage debt would create a pecuniary liability upon the mortgagor and would be covered by the definition of the word debt in s. 2(6).

We are of opinion that there is noforce in this contention. The words pecuniary liability will cover any liability which is of a monetary nature. Now the definition of a mortgage in s. 58 of the Transfer of Property Act, No. 4 of 1882, shows that though it is the transfer of an interest in specific immovable property, the purpose of the transfer is to secure the payment of money advanced or to be advanced by way of loan or to secure an existing or future debt or the performance of an engagement which may give rise to a pecuniary liability. The money advanced by way of loan, for example, which is secured by a mortgage, obviously creates a pecuniary liability. It is true that a mortgage in addition to creating the pecuniary liability also transfers interest in the specific immovable property to secure that liability nonetheless the loan or debt to secure which the mortgage is created will remain a pecuniary liability of the person creating the mortgage. Therefore a mortgage debt would create a pecuniary liability upon the mortgagor and would be covered by the definition of the word debt in s. 2(6).

edges.explanation: The holding directly answers and resolves the issue by stating that nothing in the scheme or provisions of the Act militates against or cuts down the plain meaning of 'pecuniary liability' in s. 2(6)(c).

anchor.surface_text: Let us now see whether there is anything in the scheme of the Act which in any way militates against the plain words of s. 2(6). Learned counsel for the appellant in the first place refers to sub-cl. (b) of s. 2(6) in this connection and points out that that subclause specifically deals with mortgage debts secured on any immovable property situate in the territories forming part of West Pakistan. ... Thus we see nothing in any provision of the Act or in its scheme which would cut down the meaning we have given to the words pecuniary liability as used in s. 2(6) read with sub-cl. (c) thereof.

Let us now see whether there is anything in the scheme of the Act which in any way militates against the plain words of s. 2(6). Learned counsel for the appellant in the first place refers to sub-cl. (b) of s. 2(6) in this connection and points out that that subclause specifically deals with mortgage debts secured on any immovable property situate in the territories forming part of West Pakistan. ... Thus we see nothing in any provision of the Act or in its scheme which would cut down the meaning we have given to the words pecuniary liability as used in s. 2(6) read with sub-cl. (c) thereof.

anchor.surface_text: It was also urged that if mortgage debts on property situate in India were covered by the Act, there is no machinery like s. 16 for enforcement of the creditors rights in respect thereof. This is not correct. Section 10 provides for the claim of a displaced creditor against a displaced debtor and s. 13 provides for the claim of a displaced creditor against any other person who is not a displaced debtor. Section 14(2) a tribunal can pass such decree in relation to an application under s. 13 as it thinks fit. These decrees are executable under s. 28 of the Act.

It was also urged that if mortgage debts on property situate in India were covered by the Act, there is no machinery like s. 16 for enforcement of the creditors rights in respect thereof. This is not correct. Section 10 provides for the claim of a displaced creditor against a displaced debtor and s. 13 provides for the claim of a displaced creditor against any other person who is not a displaced debtor. Section 14(2) a tribunal can pass such decree in relation to an application under s. 13 as it thinks fit. These decrees are executable under s. 28 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The last contention on behalf of the appellant is that if s. 2(6)(c) empowers a displaced creditor to make an application under s. 13 even with respect to a mortgage debt, there will be hardship to prior mortgagees or subsequent mortgagees inasmuch as these persons cannot be dealt with under the Act. ... Therefore, the interest of the prior mortgagee or the subsequent mortgagee, if any, would not be affected by a decree passed on an application under s. 13 and there is no reason therefore to cut down the plain meaning of the words used in s. 2(6)(c) on the ground that the proceedings under the Act would prejudicially affect the rights of prior or puisne mortgagees.

The last contention on behalf of the appellant is that if s. 2(6)(c) empowers a displaced creditor to make an application under s. 13 even with respect to a mortgage debt, there will be hardship to prior mortgagees or subsequent mortgagees inasmuch as these persons cannot be dealt with under the Act. ... Therefore, the interest of the prior mortgagee or the subsequent mortgagee, if any, would not be affected by a decree passed on an application under s. 13 and there is no reason therefore to cut down the plain meaning of the words used in s. 2(6)(c) on the ground that the proceedings under the Act would prejudicially affect the rights of prior or puisne mortgagees.
